Re ''Distilling the Ecstasy Buzz'' (news article, Aug. 6):
The research relating to Ecstasy has shown its well-recognized neurotoxic potential, its interference in the metabolism of serotonin and its effects on short- and long-term memory.

Animal studies show irreversible brain damage after even short-term use, and according to Dr. Alan Leshner, the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, people who take Ecstasy, ''even just a few times, will likely have long-term, perhaps permanent, problems with learning and memory.''
In short, there is no safe use of this drug in human beings.
International and federal efforts to stem the trade in and use of Ecstasy are necessary for that reason, not to ''justify their budgets.''
WILLIAM R. CALTRIDER JR. President, Center for Alcohol and Drug Research and Education Towson, Md., Aug. 7, 2000
